column2: Don't hitch hike.
Try not to travel at night.
Avoid DangerZone areas especially at night.
As a general rule city streets that include children and women suggest the area is safe for families.
If you are mugged don't fight back. It is better to lose a few dollars and a wristwatch than get injured.
Avoid incidents such as fights riots or civil disturbances at all times.
Use ATMs during the day when there are people around.
Don't share taxis with strangers.
Even if you're not sure where you're going walk like you've got a purpose.
Be discreet when map reading.
Notice the people around you. Be wary if someone seems to be taking more than a passing interest.
Don't wear expensive jewellery on obvious display.
Consider carrying a 'dummy' wallet holding a small amount of cash. If you are directly confronted by a mugger you can hand over the dummy wallet and avoid further distress.
Beware of people posing as a police officer and asking to check your money for counterfeit bills.
Stash your valuables on your person.
Don't appear to be traveling alone when meeting new people.
Plan your trip before you leave home.
Keep moving and don't stay in one spot for too long.
Try to minimise the number of bags you are carrying

While in a taxi or car service act as if someone is expecting you and will raise the alarm if you don't arrive - you might like to make a phone call or mention in passing to your driver that your boss colleague or partner is waiting for you at your destination.
Avoid travelling in a train carriage where you are the only passenger.
When you're out walking keep your bag close and hold it on the opposite side of your body to the street to avoid bag snatchers in cars or on motorcycles.
